The Democratic leadership--including Hillary--show their lack of concern for American workers when it comes to immigration policy, which in the US amounts to outsourcing by importing the cheap labor. Since the millennium, we've been importing a million immigrants annually--down by half from the '90s. The Senate immigration bill would have nearly tripled legal immigration, to nearly 3 million annually, or 1.5 New York State population equivalents per decade. True--3/4 million would have been "guest workers", but they would have had no incentive to leave after their time was up, because the bill pushed implementation of E-Verify five years into the future, but left it vulnerable. If it were legally challenged, it would be suspended until resolution, and you know that ACLU and La Raza would have challenged it.

Nice analysis but I wonder how many of those jobs would have been lost REGARDLESS of whether the US had entered into any trade pacts.  If other countries offer cheap labor, a reasonably secure legal environment and social stability, would any multi-national in search of reduced costs resist moving certain jobs to those countries?Or are we then supposed to increase import duties even though the US has had low import duties since ... well, since it was realized at the time of the Great Depression that high tariffs hurt everybody.And that's really the point, the Labor movement is living in a make-believe world.  They think we can turn the US into an island of wealth and stability while beggaring the rest of the world.   As but one example, there are those who think Mexican migration (those raping "illegal aliens") is out-of-control.  Well, it would have been a lot worse but for NAFTA.Change is tough but a vibrant economic system demands creative destruction.  And for the world to survive in peace, one of the things that is required is a vibrant economic system.Absolutely -- correct the systems excesses by reforming the tax system (higher marginal rates!) and providing a safety net and education for those whose jobs are "creatively destroyed."  But don't make something worse because of fear.

Everyone is overlooking the fact that that at the behest of our Wall Street masters our politicians have shipped all of these jobs and wealth to COMMUNIST CHINA.  Talk about selling your hangman the rope with which to hang you.  Lenin's laughs are echoing throughout his mausoleum.

Most wealth is produced by capital which comes from the  natural resources of this country ( which immigrants still call "the Mountain of Gold", and the labor used to extract the natural resources.  This wealth is distributed to those who have acquired ownership of these resources (rent collectors ) and to workers through their jobs.  The American belief that wealth is produced by effort and ability is not accurate.    There is no reason to use jobs to distribute the wealth produced by the natural resources, or to continue believing that rentiers earn their wealth.

It's so easy to succumb to an offer of huge profits, a challenge to anyone's sense of right and wrong.  That's exactly why congress has become the institution of evil and self-service, with only a few voices in the wilderness.  We voters have to keep our eyes on the goal until election day.  We want representative government.  We'll have to turn out the vote in order to get it back.  The first step would be to kick every incumbent to the curb, in order to get their attention away from the money.  We all have to ask ourselves if we would take money in exchange for doing something wrong, in exchange for doing something that would harm our fellow citizens.  If the answer is yes, then we already have the government we apparently want.

Comparing the number of jobs lost across a 12 year period to the number of total jobs "supported by exports" today makes absolutely no sense whatsoever. Set aside for now that we don't even know what "supported by exports" means. Is that 40 million jobs higher than a similar number would have been ten years ago? Considering the Chamber's silence on that topic, I suspect the answer is "no." Similarly, using California as an example of the relative benefits of trade makes absolutely no sense. They're a natural export market purely owning to their proximity to the Pacific Ocean and Asia. California also contains our powerhouse cultural industries (music, movies, video games) that can export billions of dollars of ephemeral (digital) product at almost zero cost. California is uniquely positioned to benefit more from increases in trade than any other state. Over the past 60 years owners have replaced as many workers as they can with machines. Some sectors were very resistant to that process, for whatever reason, but once we removed trade barriers with Mexico and China they instead had to compete with extremely low-cost foreign labor. Massive layoffs in manufacturing sectors created a reserve army of unemployed people, whose existence corporate America has used to basically halt wage growth for almost twenty years now. Until and unless we figure out a way to bring those millions of people back into our economy, none of us will get a raise. More trade is not the answer.

The labor problem is like having two connected water tanks. One is full and the other almost empty. If a hole develops between the tanks, the full one empties into the other. If the full tank is only about a fifth of the size of the empty tank, the water will reach an equilibrium at a very low point in the smaller tank. Global trade places a hole in our tank: between our very high standard of living and wage level, and the very low standard of living in other countries, especially those in Asia. China, in my example, is a very big tank, with a very low water level.The only way to keep water level full is to keep the tanks separate. And, not to pun, that ship has sailed. We can choose to manufacture here, at our standard of living, but it is likely that the rest of the world - the majority of the market for goods and services - will buy from a low cost producer, most likely China or another Pacific Rim country.We can change our tax structure - replace payroll taxes with Value Add taxes that affect imports as well as US production is an example - to eliminate disincentives to hiring US workers. But we most likely are never going to be able to plug the hole between the water tanks.

American manufacturing jobs left because American corporate leaders have a herd mentality and an unbending belief that it is too expensive to produce in America.  Fourty years ago they were unwilling to spend capital to upgrade plants and facilities.  There is no trade pact or political party that will change that belief.  Even though off shoring manufacturing has resulted in long lead times for manufactured components resulting in the inability to respond quickly to market changes.  There is also a national security issue with this lack of manufacturing.  There are no small motors made in the US (consumer lawn mowers, chain saws, snow blowers, compressors etc).  And we are dependent on the Russians! to provide the engines for the few space vehicles around.  What a sorry state. What if Corporate America stopped buying back their stock to improve EPS and their corporate bonuses? And instead used that capital to produce something tangible?  Good jobs go with manufacturing and manufacturing allows exports.

I believe that Mr. Edsall is incorrect when he writes that "trade, taxes and social spending are subjects that have not yet achieved progressive consensus and retain the potential to fracture the [Democratic] party."  The 2016 election is already shaping up as a critical contest between two diametrically opposed visions of America, particularly regarding taxes and social spending: the Republicans want to cut taxes for the wealthy and corporations and dismantle major parts of the safety net (i.e., Social Security, Medicare, Obamacare, etc.); and the Democrats want everyone to pay their "fair share" of taxes (which means increase taxes for the wealthy and corporations) and strengthen and secure the safety net. If the Republicans win the presidency and retain their majorities in the House and Senate then the already deleterious polarization that is tearing this country apart will reach a critical point.
With the Republicans, whatever one thinks of them, one knows what one is getting. What does one expect to get from the Democrats - and what does one get?

The answer is not to restrict trade but to increase union participation, especially across national boundaries. The AFL-CIO and other American unions have failed workers by adopting an exclusively national policy, pitting American workers against workers in Mexico, China, Vietnam, etc. Business is international, there are fewer and fewer borders for corporations and this is the future. In general, it's a positive thing: isolated states are in constant conflict; there is more peace and security now than at any time in the past. But the power of the corporations must be met with a powerful labor force and this will only come about through an international labor consciousness. Marx was half right: workers aren't going to take over the world, but their solidarity across borders is necessary to raise wages and the standard of living for everyone.

Mr. Edsall in your calculation's if you remove Oil from the export figures how strong is the downtick? I mean, specifically, Texas being the #1 Exporter. Remove Oil from THAT equation and what would it look like. If you please?

The pro-trade oligarchs own the Republican Party and are close to gaining control of the Democratic Party. Money is buying everything in the US; political power, economic power, the judicial system. All of the Republican candidates and Ms. Clinton are pro-trade. The only hope for the working class and the middle class in the country is a Bernie Sanders presidency. Oligarchy or Sanders, that is the real choice for 2016.

The author needs to look at Germany where manufacturing jobs are still possible. The EU does have a 25% duty on imports, but more important is that the buyers are willing to pay more for quality goods. Another item is that European countries force firms that export jobs to pay for the retraining of workers who are unemployed as a result. This needs to be made universal. Aside from this, the headlines make it clear that China is a fascist state--that is the government and industry cooperate completely. The US really needs to recognize this and take action against currency manipulation, violation of environmental rules and slave labor wages. I suggest import duties on Chinese goods to take these factors into account.

De-coupling the job loss effects of automation from off-shoring further confounds the truth. US GDP of manufactured goods continues to rise, counter to the employment data.Several years after NAFTA, my father, a 45+ year worker in the steel industry said, "We are making more steel of higher quality with less people than we ever have". Manufacturing jobs is much more than a trade issue. When given a choice between human workers and robots, all else being equal, any responsible executive will choose automation every time. 3.5 million truck drivers in the US need to worry about self-driving trucks, not off-shoring or the TPP.

This is a superb column. Finally hitting the issue in the bulls-eye.  I've been waiting to hear just why the common citizen should support Obama's TPP, and the answer is, we shouldn't.You know, the rage wouldn't be quite as hot, if it seemed like something, ANYTHING, was being done to make some jobs for America.  Are we rebuilding the railroads?  No, we can't even get money for roads.  Are we rebuilding bridges, which are falling down and killing people?  No.  Are we building green industries?  No.What we are doing is bankrupting our children with college expenses. Corporations are clamoring to bring in more and more foreigners to do the jobs of Americans. And the CEOs keep getting bonuses.Washington, Wall Street and the billionaires are not only NOT helping Americans, they are kicking us while we are down and spitting in our faces.

What is best for the U.S. does not seem to be part of the equation.  Corporate profits vs. better compensation for labor is the dividing line.  The corporate profits side would have a stronger argument if corporations paid their fair share of taxes to support the general welfare.  In today's system, it is a reverse Robin Hood scenario.  Corporate profits increase as workers' compensation declines and the corporations receive more and more government services while contributing fewer dollars (if any at all).
If you're in favor of oligarchy, income inequality, and voodoo economics, why run as a Democrat?  Because you'd have too many competitors if you were to run as a Republican?

The Bivens findings say it all: exchanging capital for labor leads to perpetual inequality and the pauperization of labor. Democratic politicians must constantly hammer home this message to American voters if there is any hope of salvaging the middle class way of life in this country.

This is the wonderful "advertising" for Senator Bernie Sanders' campaign for President. Every story about the rich finding ways grab more and more political power in America illustrates clearly how desperately we need a candidate who can win an election on the basis of his ideas rather than on how many billionaire contributors he has.We need a revolution to "take back our country." Let's get behind Bernie Sanders and see if this country's revolutionary spirit is still alive somewhere in the hearts of the majority of its citizens.

The problem is that one corporation could donate significantly more resources to support it's candidate, than a thousand of American citizens, thanks to Super PAC. Although, PAC has limitations, corporations can also use it for their own purposes, they just oblige employees to donate money for the right candidate. As a result, candidates who really supported by the people of America, receive significantly less financial support. Not very fair, is not it?
I will not vote for any candidate that privately or publicly embraces a Super PAC. Go Bernie.

I am going to vote for the democratic party on all levels.  I personally do not want to see a single republican in any office of any level of government.  Driving force behind the GOP (Government Operatives for Pay)  The Koch brothers didn't just inherit their father's fortune. They also inherited his politics. In 1958, Fred Koch was a founding member of the John Birch Society, the right-wing extremist group that opposed civil rights and claimed that both the Democratic and Republican Parties were infiltrated by the Communist Party. In his 1960 self-published book, A Business Man Looks at Communism, Fred Koch wrote that "The colored man looms large in the Communist plan to take over America," and that welfare was a secret plot to attract rural blacks and Puerto Ricans to Eastern cities to vote for Communist causes and "getting a vicious race war started." The John Birch Society helped fuel a wave of hysteria against unions, civil rights groups, intellectuals, public schools, liberal clergy and others whom they considered a threat to America.  Charles and David Koch do what their father told them to do, their minions do what they tell them to do. Their political activities are primarily dedicated to eliminating government regulation of business and lowering taxes on the rich.Essentially, the G"OPP" are being paid by Koch Brothers to work out their father’s war on communism. If you look at it, this is the Republicant platform wrapped in prejudice.

And this is what our Supreme Court calls democracy, and not what it seems to be:  a version of racketeering and conspiracy, election fraud, and rule by the few (oligarchy).Add it together with voting district gerrymandering by both parties, and maybe you’ve got Russia…or a capitalist version of China.  At least you’ve got something that seems foreign to American soil.Either stay home on election day, or vote for Bernie Sanders.  No matter what the NYT tells you, Clinton and her husband are part of the problem.

This is one reason that I choose not to vote in primaries. I don't know about other states but once you vote in a primary in Texas you get on mailing lists that are darn near impossible to get off.  I receive enough unsolicited political  junk mail to fill my recycle bin several times over each primary season.  I also receive political junk phone calls thanks to loopholes in the do not mail law.  I do wonder if any of these Super Pacs are going to take the time to help the unregistered voter get their voter registration card and voter ID card?  Probably not.For all those candidates that railed against the Supreme Court as being an activist court, I wonder how many of them railed against the Citizens United ruling.

It would be so much simpler and efficient to just allow the PACs to run to country directly.   Every four years we could hold an auction and the highest bidder gets to run the country as he or she sees fit until the next auction.  No congress, no court system, just President Super PAC ruling by decree.

Knock yourselves out boys and girls.  WE are going to elect Ms. Hillary Rodham Clinton President of the United States in 2016 and elect a Congress and state legislatures/governors who want to restore democracy in America.  First up - a constitutional amendment that says corporations are not people - including supposed "non profit" ones - and money is not speech.

Thanks to Citizens United once again- another chapter in the total corruption of the American political system.Any person with half a brain could have predicted the depth of monied corruption that would follow this dastardly decision. I am certain the SCOTUS did indeed know this as well. So, I must ask myself why did these 5 justices ever vote for this? Is there a secret bank account somewhere for them in the Caymen's perhaps or are they just so rabidly right they really think this country should be ruled by corporate interests and not the people? It's sickening.On a side note... I noticed the pic-college kids may find Rand Paul appealing right now but I fear they have no sense of history or understanding of government or life in general. The very ones who want a small enough government to drown in the bathtub are usually the very ones who put their hand out for government assistance when any disaster that comes their way. No regulations eh? Go talk to Elizabeth Warren about weak banking regs were behind the crash of 1929 and 2008. Want clean air, food, water, medicine? Won't have that without regulations. Want fuel efficient and safe cars and safe kids' car seats, etc? Won't have that without regulations. You want your parents covered under Medicare? Not without government. Want a banana republic? You will have that without regulations.

Endless streams of unregulated money provided by wealthy corporations and individuals used to convince the public to vote for the candidate that best represents that wealthy corporation or individual under the absurdly thin veil of operating independently of the candidate.It truly boggles my mind that this is acceptable in the United States of America. The only reason this isn't corruption is because our Supreme Court legalized it.

So, the day has finally arrived.  No more subterfuge.  No more hiding behind 'disclaimers' nobody believed anyway.  To paraphrase Coolidge, 'The business of America is...business in the business of electing candidates to public office who like business running things."How's that been working out since our 'CEO-in-chief' set that tone in 2001?Madison Avenue is going from selling us soap and 'little blue pills', to selling us on the 'wisdom' of Wall Street.  I tuned out that message a long time ago, and I hope the rest of America does too.  The only expertise Business has in public policy is in protecting Business, and convincing voters that it has some kind of lock on 'expertise' (while all other experts are demonized on the pro-business propaganda network known as Fox Business)I hope America likes flames coming out of its kitchen faucets.  There's going to be a lot more of that, if Business succeeds in taking over our public institutions.

The level of fanatical partisanship on the part of reader-commenters here is every bit as rigid and narrowly focused as is that of the wild-eyed Tea Party FOXNews cheering squad on the right. Take off the tinfoil beanies--the NYTimes does not have an “agenda” to sink or promote anyone’s candidacy. This “if you’re not with us, you’re against us” childishness is deplorable in an educated adult readership who ought to know better--they interpret any journalistic analysis short of outright support as conspiratorial bias against their chosen candidate. Look, I like Sanders and will support and vote for him but I know he has a very rough uphill battle. Everyone is comparing him to Obama circa 2007. Unfortunately, his situation is closer to that of Dean in 2003. Even without making any mistakes analogous to “the scream” (which was unfairly taken out of context), Sanders’ unapologetically self-described Socialism will be an extremely tough sell outside of the urban and college-town bubbles in which most of us here live, even though his individual policies are sensible, fair and even populist. Most voters are, alas. “low-information” and have neither the inclination nor the time to look behind the labels--be they political party, cultural or ethnic.If he were running for Pres. of WI, NY, CA, IL or New England he’d win in a walk. Unfortunately, he has the rest of the country to convince--with an electorate lacking the necessary attention span to be convinced.

If most voters are like me, then we are at this stage looking around while realizing we already have a "good enough" candidate in the winds. To turn this to a solid vote takes an undefined something that may best be described as follows: Democrats need to "fall in love" with a candidate (while Republicans are happy to "fall in line" behind a candidate). To hitch to Bernie's wagon, would in the final analysis, be a matter of reason not the heart. It's like marrying some one not because she (or he) is the subject of your passionate love, but because she (or he) serves your interest. To look at the choice between Hillary and Bernie, I think she offers most things he does. Although I admit three is a little lingering doubt that Hillary may not be as committed as Bernie would be. But on the other hand, it must be realized that Bernie would have a huge hill to climb to be accepted by the general voters in November 2016. Hillary is a surer bet. At this stage anyway. The way things look to me (now) is this: I'd rather get 60% or 70 %  of what I need with 80% certainty than get 100 % of what I need with 40% or 50 % of certainty. Only Bernie's campaign (and Hillary's undisclosed troubles) would change these percentages. You see, this is the way a rationalist looks at  things not the one in love!)

Sanders would fit right in with Canada's NDP Party. A return to "true democracy"     Government by,for and of the people.Is America ready for that? Not the pseudo-democracy offered by the Democrats and GOP.And yes Sweden,Norway,Denmark and Canada are perfect examples of nation's which support the "poorer members of their citizens." Not,just the bankers and super rich 1%.Will American's respond to his message.That,is open to debate.
Bernie can beat Hillary, and he can beat whatever weed is remnant from the poisoned Bush family root.

CAN BERNIE ACTUALLY WIN?Who would have thought that it was even remotely possible for Lisa Murkowski to retain her Senate seat a few years back, when voters had to write her name in by-hand on the ballots?Bernie can win if: 1) enough people CAN vote for him (he gets on the ballot)2) Enough people DO vote for him, rather than support him only to telephone pollsters3) The votes are counted correctly (Bush-v-Gore, anyone?, Stalin: votes don't matter, only who counts them)The biggest thing he has going for him is cross-over appeal. Although perceived of as an ultra-liberal, he is likely to pull votes from MANY right-wingers who would NEVER, EVER vote for Hillary.In fact, I predict that Hillary will not win, ultimately because of:1) The huge numbers of voters who say that they will never vote for her.2) Instead of the authentic Senator HRC, she is becoming just the latest LeftWing "machine" politician whose pitch to the voters is that they want to "fight" for you, be your champion, & etc. That won't be a magnet for independent voters. That is what killed Gore back in 2000 (and SCOTUS)Installing GWB/Cheney was one of the worst disasters that has ever been visited upon our nation. Its hard to imagine a President Gore going into Iraq.Gore's agenda was to pay OFF, the national debt in 10 years, while GWB's promise was to tax-cut our way to nirvana. We all know the outcome: double the National Debt (again, thanks RR!);  worst recession since the 30s

Remember when the NYT and other media said that Bill Thompson didn't have a prayer against Mike Bloomberg for NYC mayor and then the election was close?  And then it was found that Thompson could have won if the media hadn't discouraged voters from going to the polls?The NYT needs to stop discouraging voters who are trying to redress the excesses of a political system ruled by the One Percent.  Sanders is fueling hope on the part of ordinary Americans that we can turn this system around before it is too late for all of us.

Most Americans aren't worthy of a Bernie Sanders; so many are selfish and our rugged individualism has evolved into a "what's in it for me?" greediness. That the GOP is still such a potent force is proof that we do not deserve such a mensch.

First of all, there is a big organizational event happening later this month and that will answer the ground troops questions as to how many and how committed. Until then to dismiss him is highly speculative.Next I object to the tone:"People may be surprised to learn that Mr. Sanders isn’t some starry-eyed political fantasist, despite his socialist leanings..."We do not hear conservatives and others described as starry-eyed political fantasists despite their wanting to privatize Social Security and to turn Medicare into a voucher program.Note to the writer and the New York Times:We, the American people most likely to vote in the Primaries and Caucuses DO NOT WANT A HILLARY CORONATION.Not one vote has been cast, not one ballot has been published and nobody out here gives a damn about the horse race. We want a President suited to the challenges our country faces.Ms Clinton is still trying to figure out what she will public describe as her core values as she has none that would appeal to Democratic voters. Senator Sanders sounds like a real Democrat despite being an Independent unafraid of the words liberal, progressive and Democratic Socialist.

I live in Portland and went to the rally yesterday evening in which Bernie spoke. He supports all the right things if you are a progressive like myself, yet he does not say a word about how he thinks America will pay for any, much less all, of the initiatives he'd like to undertake!  The one thing he mentioned was a  tax on "Wall street speculators". A popular idea, no doubt, but it won't raise any significant money and will certainly drive most of that activity overseas anyway!!!  I'd consider voting for him if and when he comes up with more than just rhetoric, even if it is my kind of rhetoric!!!

As a life-long Republican until the 2003 debacle in Iraq and the 2008 market scandal, I see Senator Sanders as a breath of fresh air, a purposeful visionary who has the people of this country at heart.He might be the Sen. Gene McCarthy of 2016!!! for those who remember how the '68 campaign was turned upside down, and the unbeatable LBJ was defeated.Yes he can!! defeat Hilary and give the country a truly new choice of leadership.

I find Clinton's candidacy unimpressive and uninspiring. I resent the fact that I am suppose to think of her candidacy as a forgone conclusion. Outside of the urban beltways Clinton is despised. Although those in control of the Democratic party have drunk the Clinton kool-aid and will nominate her as the Democratic nominee, this country will not elect her as president. The Clinton family dynastic aspiration is like the emperor who had no clothes. They believe they are wanted when in reality they are not. These are critical times in our nation and the last thing we need is a tentative party hack leading the country based on pollster reports.I am a Democrat and I will not support Hillary Clinton. Give me Bernie Sanders or anyone else with an idea and a vision. Give me a presidential candidate with the guts to actually deal with the ailments of our country.

Actually, the real question is: Will Democratic voters, who have witnessed incompetence, inactivity, cowardliness and lack of leadership from Democratic politicians over the past forty years, totally support the one candidate who expresses true democratic ideas and positions.I've been a Democrat for more than 50 years, but for many of those years, I no longer knew what my party stood for! I have seen Democrats make some memorable achievements; Recoveries from two disastrous Republican recessions, President Bill Clinton's economic successes in job growth and deficit reduction, the Affordable Care Act, possibly the greatest piece of legislation since the Civil Rights laws, and then watched as the Democrats said and did nothing, while the Republican propaganda machine and it's allies, discredited these achievements through lies and falsehoods! Remarkably, the Democratic Party has even failed to establish itself as the party of the middle class!Finally, because a Democrat, Bernie Sanders has spoken out to denounce right wing propaganda, and championed progressive issues, We are beginning to see the rebirth of the true Democratic party and the rebuilding of a more fair and prosperous America!

Sanders pushes all my buttons. He is the first candidate to whom I have ever made a cash contribution--be it smaller than I wish it could be. He brings a message that millions of US citizens have have long wanted to hear. One  concerned with advancing the interests  and its middle class  and the Nation  rather than with personal and party aggrandizement. If Sanders can  can get his message out to everyone I'm confident he will win.

Considering that all of the rest of the presidential candidates are bought ...lock, stock and barrel ... and Bernie Sanders isn't resonates with the American people. Bernie voted against the Iraq war, Hillary voted for it !  Bernie knows all the trade deals have been one-way and all have contributed to our trade deficits of billions/trillions of dollars and caused millions of American jobs to be lost. Bernie knows our wages are lower with these trade agreements and out of control immigration that suppresses wages in our country.  He also gets it that the 1% don't pay their fair share in taxes to sustain our infrastructure while making college education unaffordable. Bernie is against TPP, it undermines our sovereignty and laws. TPP was the breaking point for me and the established Democratic Party blew it big time on this and that includes Hillary !  Bernie'16 !

As much as I'd like to see Bernie elected, what could he really accomplish with a republican congress?  And is he really electable?  Probably not.  Hillary will get most of the votes of women, blacks, and hispanics.  That's about 70% of the electorate.  Some educated white men will vote for Bernie, but there aren't enough of them.  One thing is certain.  There will be a democrat in the W.H. in 2017.  Regrettably that democrat will face the same congress Obama has faced until we do away with gerrymandering.  And republicans, due to gerrymandering, actually think the majority of Americans support their agenda?

Sure people are discouraged by the stupendous power of government and the intrigue that only the insiders can fathom. So they like a nice guy in the early round of the fake campaign. The question is not whether he can win but can he be President. He can win like Jimmy Carter and still find himself utterly unprepared to be President. It's not what you are against. It's what you are going to do.

Brenie Sanders offers an alternative for the confused and frustrated voters who want a leader with a simple message.  The complicity of the issues we face far transends the comprehension of most.  After all, by the definition, we are a nation with an average IQ of 100.  And an IQ of 100 is about one standard deviation less than what it takes to work through the maze of the New York Times, but sufficient enough to get  swept along by simple hate messaging.  Simply put, we are a nation of dummies who can be easily swayed because we collectively lack the intellectual ability to comprehend to complex issues.  Bernie Sanders, as did Barack Obama, has simple answers that appeal to simple minds with disasterous consequences. And come to think of it, about 83 percent of the population have an IQ of less than 110, which is the threshold for attaining a college degree in a technical subject, but sufficient to find the way to a Bernie Sanders political rally.

A difference between Sanders and Obama is that Obama had been working for a long long time to lay the groundwork for running in '08 with operatives like Axelrod and Plouffe doing all the really extensive ground work. He didn't just pull it out of his sleeve because a lot of people showed up at his events. It wasn't wishful thinking or enthusiasm, it was laying the foundation very carefully for a long time.

I live in Vermont and I think this question is too simplistic at this point.  Senator Sanders has always been underestimated and my late husband, a revered physician, said being underestimated is ultimately to one's advantage --   for obvious reasons.  He is a fine politician, but more importantly, an amazing human being: consistent, thoughtful, articulate, smart and true.  Years ago he spoke at my mother-in-law's memorial service -- imagine that -- and I attended dozens of his town meetings and asked tough questions that he answered with facts, conviction and understated passion.  He is who he is,a fighter for us all and one of the reasons I am proud to be a Vermonter.  No one is without flaws, but there is not a Republican in the race that can hold a candle to him -- examples abound, but their craven responses  to gun violence, Donald Trump's idiocy are starters.  In 2007 I wrote a letter to the Times that bemoaned political dynasties.  Plus ce change, plus ce la meme chose.  We can do better.

Better question: can the .new York Times cover an election in any way other than as  a horse race, when the first *actual* race is just under seven months away? There is so much to dig into, in history (um, not as done, snarkily, by Sarah Lyall), and, crucially, in positions taken. Why does the Times insist on taking the most shallow, obvious, unhelpful approach?

Unless Bernie happens to be the man the Party wants to be their person at bat for 2016 I don't think he has much of a chance. I think he's the better candidate but that doesn't always work the way it should. It seems to me that 'we the people' have less and less to do with the process every cycle.
Keep it simple:  Yes.  Bernie can definitely beat Hillary.

I will vote for Bernie Sanders. I am a big supported of the programs he advocates. In addition, I trust his much more than Hillary on foreign affairs decisions. Hillary is sold out to corporations, the status quo and Israel.

It's disturbing that the writer discredits Sanders because he is not "well financed" and without a huge staff. The million$$$ spent on these campaigns is absurd, especially the ridiculous negative TV ads - oh boy, can't wait for those...

The question shows the Times bias toward madam neo-con.Same question was asked 8 years ago about Barak Obama. Guess what happened?WE-the voters-will decide this election, not NY Times or FIX News. Just because she's named Clinton and a woman doesn't get her the presidency. I don't recall Obama going before crowds asking them isn't it about time to have a black person as president?She is the least qualified for the job. In discussing the chances of Bernie Sanders, the author (Patric Healy) concludes, " there remains the threshold question: Do Americans hunger for radical change intensely enough...."  Do you really consider what Mr. Sanders is calling for to be "radical change"?  During most much of our history his "radical" program would have been considered centrist.  This was supported by such well known Republican radicals as Abraham Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, Dwight Eisenhower and even Richard Nixon.  At what point in our history did ultra-right wing conservatism come to be re-defined as centrist?

I think the perception that Clinton "is widely considered more mainstream and electable than Mr. Sanders" is beginning to shift. As more people learn about Sanders' policies and consistent message/record, they see that he comes from a very American and mainstream view of governance, a bit like "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington." He reminds us all of longstanding American values of fairness, plainspokenness, and speaking up for the little guy instead of the vested interests in Washington and Wall St. Though he is clearly a left wing candidate, his honest message resonates with independents and even many Republicans in Vermont and everywhere. It's an uphill battle, but he really can win.

Maybe it is just me, but I get tired of reading this kind of statement: "People may be surprised to learn that Mr. Sanders isn’t some starry-eyed political fantasist, despite his socialist leanings and visions of moving America closer to a welfare-state system like those of Denmark and Sweden, which he praises as models of fair-minded government on the campaign trail."Sanders is a Franklin Roosevelt democrat who places value on average citizens. He promotes equality through education, health care, social security and some sort of safety net. All mainstream positions in the general population, just not among the one per cent.  The writer's language  makes it sound like he is outside the mainstream. The only mainstream is outside of the one per cent. No Senator, independent or otherwise, who does not understand political reality would survive as long as Sanders. He isn't perfect, loves the F-35 and Israel, but he isn't the war mongering wall street loving Obama or HC [both similar to the 15 rs], and his record gives much fairer shake to the average person.  I'll vote for him. us army 1969-1971/california jd

I'm old enough to have lived through the candidacies (starting in 1948) of Henry Wallace, Eugene McCarthy, George McGovern, John Anderson, and Ralph Nader.  All good men. Bernie Sanders has three things in his favor. The first is that he appears genuine in the sense that his campaign is based upon policy positions that he has been advocating for years, rather than last week or last month. The second thing is that he could not be more different than the hyper organized, hyper calculating, and hyper controlling Hillary Clinton for whom "genuineness" is something to be checked off on a form prepared by some long-term worshipful aide. When reporters ask Bernie a policy question, they receive a straight answer that is both logical and understandable. Not only has Hillary mostly avoided the press, but even when asked a policy question her responses are measured, calculated, and possibly different than her views in the past. The third thing is that when he speaks publicly, Bernie galvanizes people; Hillary bores them or puts them to sleep.

Good column.  It reveals Bernie Sanders as a political pragmatist with an extremely appealing message.  I agree that Sanders will do well--and perhaps prevail-- in Iowa and New Hampshire.  After that, I'm as uncertain as anyone.The silver lining thus far is that Sanders' message is being heard and is being greeted enthusiastically.  In other words, the political pros may be writing Sanders off, but the voters aren't.  That and Sanders's fund-raising prowess to date ($15 million and counting) are hopeful signs for this young campaign.  If this trend continues, Sanders will help to shape the Democratic stance on the issues, whether or not he is the nominee: a successful outcome.Sanders' directness is bracing and-- unlike every other major party candidate-- he is forthrightly addressing the economic issues that concern most Americans.  Compared to Sanders, the other candidates are at best vapid.I also want to note that the Times's coverage of the Sanders campaign, while gradually improving, has been spotty and centered on whether Sanders can depose Clinton.  There has been almost no coverage in the Times of the issues that Sanders is addressing and the reactions that he is eliciting on matters of proposed policy.  As a result, I'm relying on other media outlets (the Washington Post, Politico, regional newspapers) to follow the Sanders campaign.  The Times can and should do better. Or is the scant and unsatisfactory coverage that the Times is according Sanders willful?

Sanders' praise for Denmark and Sweden's welfare systems is so broad that it sounds like he would like the middle class to support the rest of the world.  He needs to explain his plan in detail before people can vote on it.

Whether or not Sen. Sanders can eke out a victory against Mrs. Clinton, the fact remains that his presence in the race can only make her a better candidate. At some point in the not-so-distant future she's going to have to confront Bernie's message head-on and she's going to have to appropriate much of his agenda even while scurrying away from the "Socialist" label that the senator proudly and/or stubbornly clings to.  In effect, she's going to have to serve as the born-again messenger of the senator's message while reminding the voters that it's her time and her turn and her ability to make history in a way that he cannot.  (Then again, he'd be the first Jewish president, wouldn't he?) On the other hand, I'm still hoping for Joe...
Welfare system like "Denmark and Sweden?"  But what does Sanders propose when half the population can't take care of themselves or their children?

When capitalism works as intended (meaning money makes money), it produces plutocracy. This is because a small percentage of the population always has (and has had) almost all the money. So when "money makes money," those few make most of the money that money makes, and wealth (and the power that is wealth) concentrates in a few hands. If you want to have a "growth" economy that uses profit as a mechanism, you either have to accept radical inequality or you implement high taxes on super-incomes and concentrated wealth and distribute the proceeds through the rest of society.

Reagan and his robber baron masters suckered us into voo-doo "trickle down" economics and laughingly gave us the Laffer Curve.  The result of Reagan's lies was an unmitigated disaster. Nothing trickled down. The middle class got squeezed to the point that we our "consumer" economy is now looking at years of anemic GDP growth. Instead of having the rich pay their fair share, we reduced their tax rates and thereby accumulated massive national debt that (unless we change the current tax code) will be left for our children and grandchildren to deal with.So let's try the inverse of Reaganomics, and let's go back to the truly progressive income tax rates that we had in the 1950s.  Put some purchasing power back in the hands of the middle class and watch our economy (and tax revenues) grow!  That would be a true win-win situation.

Can the "help" from the top come as a result of free and open elections. When I say free I mean free of voter suppression, Gerrymandering, having the vote on a non-working day or even a couple of days, free from the Electoral College which gives too great a weight to less populous states, free of political TV ads that are nothing but id driving propaganda, free of 2 year election cycles where 3 months is adequate everywhere else, free of "dark money" and corporate person-hood (whatever that means), free from money is speech (no money is power not speech). This isn't too Utopian because like universal health care, the voting system I refer to is rife in more egalitarian countries.

Inequality must certainly be addressed. And marginal tax rates for the 1% can and should be increased. But if we simply take money away from the 1% and redistribute it across the 99% without addressing the real reasons for the breakdown in upward mobility we will be kidding ourselves. We'll be right back where we started before long. Imagine a world where we genuinely work to overcome the ingrained systemic obstacles to equality of opportunity (vs. the lip service paid to this now) - there could be plenty of fully qualified people to take the place of the 1% for a little less pay. The competition would pull the highest wages and bonuses down to more reasonable levels. And there would be no more golden parachutes for CEOs who destroy their companies for their own short term gain, wreck the lives of their employees and then walk away scott-free. Is there any politician courageous enough to make this their goal?

Since the '70s, the ultra-rich have invested a lot of money in massive campaign donations, lobbying juggernauts, "think tank" funding and PR advocacy. But somehow, most people see the current inequality not as a return on this investment in tilting the playing field, but as the fair outcome of a "free market." ?

The author talks about the bottom 90% versus the top 10%, and the economic inequality between the 2 groups. What the author conveniently ignores, and in fact most commentators in this column are ignoring, is that the top 10% is comprised primarily of professionals - doctors, lawyers, engineers, etc. These are people who have spent years getting bachelors, masters, and PhD degrees, and have been successful at establishing a good career. It's not fair to demonize these people for all the hard work they have done to get to where they are, or say that they need to be pulled down in order to help the bottom 90%. Doesn't the American dream consist of working hard to get ahead? If we start pulling these people down, then what does that say about the value we place on hard work?I do agree that favorable tax treatment of certain sources of income (e.g., capital gains for hedge fund managers) needs to be examined because they are being abused. But don't lump the upper middle class with the uber-rich - that's not fair to those who have worked hard to maintain that upper middle class lifestyle. In my view, the way forward is to remove all the favorable tax exemptions and regulations and institute a flat tax for 99% of the population. Add an additional tax for incomes above $1 million, regardless of the source. Reduce the size of the IRS since tax submissions for the majority of the people will be very, very simple, and use these savings to fund programs for the needy.

"(I assume here that raising the minimum wage would not have reduced the income of those in the top 10 percent.)"This is not what my research shows. In fact, increasing the minimum wage does decrease the share of income going to (at least) the top 1% when you look at state-level data. Why is this? Because inequality is increasing because of a change in the relative bargaining power between workers and firms. As workers lose their bargaining power, the share of income going to the bottom 50% (or even bottom 90%) falls, and the share going to the top 1% rises.So what can be done? Increasing the minimum wage is certainly one way to increase workers' bargaining power by setting a wage floor. Making it easier for workers to organize would be another way to increase bargaining power. And finally, increasing top marginal tax rates should also help by reducing the incentive executives have to reduce labor costs.

Simply making the top 1% "finance" the bottom 99% may not do it. I have a hunch that the 1% people are competing among themselves? They are busy fending off their own kind to stay in the tip of the pyramid. Achieving a more equal society requires basic culture change in our attitude and ideal toward being equal as opposed to being special.

Finally, the NY Times has had the backbone to state plainly what has been clear for so long to those willing to read between the lines.The goal is income inequality, at all costs, indeed at any cost, including the very destruction of wealth. In this literally insane view, we will all be better off if the top 1% and their wealth were sunk to the bottom of the sea. We would all certainly be more equal; and doesn't equality mean happiness?In a free society, wealth will flow to those with the skills, talents, and drive to earn it. In a global economy that is true to the nth degree. Confiscation cannot achieve what its adherents believe it will: wealth for all. Instead it will create equality but only in the form of equal poverty. We will all be equal, sharing scraps and crumbs when at least some of us could have had cake.

The tremendous focus on income inequality is very appealing.  However, I would argue that reducing poverty should be our primary focus.  Many assert that you can not reduce poverty as long as income inequality exist.This argument is clearly untrue.  The best example is China in the last 40 years.  The per capita income started at less than $1 dollar a day, qualify by UN standards as "utter poverty".  Over 600 million people have been lifted out of poverty into the middle class. Recently and today, income inequality is even higher in China than the U.S.  In fact, Mao kept things horribly bad by insisting everyone should be equally poor (no income inequality).  Another example is the industrialization of Britain and the US with lords with vast holdings and robber barons.  The industrialization of these two countries caused Dickensian conditions, but undoubtedly both the US and Britain were much better for it.Income inequality is a symptom much more so than a cause.  Access to education, a fairer tax system, blacklisting ex-convicts, a fairer judicial system are all more important factors that require urgent solutions.

The marketplace aka society places different values on various skills. Many of the lowest skill sets have been replaced by robots thereby displacing humans many of whom were in manufacturing. Minimum wages apply to jobs valued minimally in terms of skills needed. Certainly minimum wages need to be fair and adjusted to inflation. The causes of income inequality are many including poor education, lack of work ethic, teenage pregnancy, job scarcity and government job programs which are ineffective. Criminal records are also a contributor to the problem. All the problems cited need to be addressed meaningfully for the poor to have better lives. Lifting those at the bottom is uplifting and positive. Redistribution tactics only punish the successful while failing to address the causes of income inequality. Assisting the the poor by pulling them up is admirable and necessary. Punishing higher earners with greater skills is unfair and divisive let alone Un American.
Two policies correlate overwhelmingly to lower poverty rates:Cash welfare benefits-  spending-

Low wage workers, at this point, also include many people who in the past would have been solidly middle class. All the professional workers who now work as contingent workers are the source of part of the declining middle class and have been robbed by our economy. As people with credentials and skills, they are still very much in demand, but are paid a pittance. Count the adjunct professors, designers, lawyers and others working only on contract. It's not like they aren't hired. There is lots of poorly paid, part time work available.The executive ranks pulled these people down because they represent high costs to business (and legislatures, who feed the .1% and control policy debates), and this is part of what is still hollowing out the middle class. I am totally sympathetic with low wage employees (who rarely get full time hours), and are generally treated as valueless, replaceable entities.The real problem is that business (and its legislative arm)  has no interest in conceiving of employees as anything but a cost. The highest incomes do not come to earners, and those who get salaries in the billions are not earning them. We must break the cycle of wealth traveling uphill, and the charade that these people have any but their own interests in mind. They have many minions on payroll working to keep this the way wealth sustains itself.
We will hear, again and again, the argument that preventing the ultra-rich from continuing to vacuum up all the economy's gains, and more, would be freedom-destroying communism.

Tax rates over the last 30 yrs have clearly been the #1 driver of income inequality followed by trade agreements that benefit the 10%ers but have been a negative for  the 90%. Why has no one suggested a return to the pre-Reagan tax rates that discouraged the extreme overcompensation that is now rampant among 1%ers. The 70s were the peak of US income equality. So all you 20, 30 and 40 somethings that weren't born yet, or old enough to pay taxes, Google the tax rates of the time, the 1%ers compensation of that era and the 90-10 spread of that time. The enrichment of the 10%, and particularly the 1% has come at a steep cost to the 90%. Bring back the steeply graduated tax rates (sorry Rand) of the 60's and 70's and stop TTIP and TPA .

I see two main problems with this.1. Scheiber's argument rests on the claim that rapid growth for the very affluent precludes rapid growth for everyone else. That would greatly concern me. But I don't know of any evidence to support it. Why doesn't Scheiber share his evidence with us?2. Scratch Scheiber's argument and what you really find is the same old same old attempt to provoke our envy of the rich for his own political and professional profit. I hope we are better than he thinks we are.

Stopping the flow of illegal aliens and deporting those already here would reduce the supply of low-wage, low-skill labor.  Obviously, this would cause wages to rise.  However, those on the political left are more concerned with increasing the supply of their voters than in enforcing our nation's laws.

In the 1950s and 1960s this country thrived and became the economic engine that ruled the world. A huge part of that growth was because of the high taxes being levied on high incomes. Rather than pay the people at the top enormous salaries, at least half of which would go in taxes, companies put that money into research and development and paid the workers well for the fruits of their labor. In turn, the American consumer had more discretionary income to buy the products American companies made.The answer to lessening inequality is many-faceted; however, raising taxes on the highest earners and paying a living wage to the people who make the highest earners' success possible will start cutting the class distinctions and grow the economy. Another idea is placing a small tax on each stock trade and start taxing investment income the same as working income. Income is income.

Just when has income ever been equal?  In the Old Testament, we hear about the "rich man and the poor man".  Thus it has always been.  Today, many nof the poor are living lifestyles those in the past could only dream about.  Big screen TV's, smart phones, new fashionable clothing, eating out.  No poor person before has EVER lived so well.When the minimum wage is raised to that degree, the ones hurt are once again the Middle Class as I can promise you, there wages will not increase.  If someone is now earning $20 an hr after many years of work, he will not get a raise to bring it in proportion to a new-hire at minimum wage.  We already have many cleaning help getting $25 an hr for unskilled labor, while the math tutor with a masters degree only gets $35.Much of poverty today is caused by substance abuse, smoking (very expensive), and by buying prepared foods or fast food.  Don't tell me they're too tired to cook after their long working hours, or that they don't have fresh food available as studies have shown that just isn't true.  Everyone is tired at the end of the workday, including SAHM's with young children, but that doesn't mean one should have meals prepared for them.  We need to bring Home Ec back into the Middle Schools so that EVERYONE - both boys and girls - learns how to fix simple, inexpensive nutritious meals.  Maimonidies said  it very well when he said "Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day; teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime."
The bottom of the income scale is closely correlated to the bottom of the education scale. If someone can't learn basic math & English no one will hire them. Certainly not @ $120 per day.

Simply reducing or eliminating the difference of the tax on income derived from capital versus the tax on earned income would go a long way to reducing inequality.  I do note that beginning with the Reagan tax cuts on high earners was the the real beginning of the C-Suite salary boom led by the increase CEO pay.  Why pillage the investors for a seven or eight figure income when you would have to pay 60% in taxes?   With the Reagan cuts, suddenly the CEO and CFO and COO could keep a lot more of the boodle.
It's time to bring back 90% the marginal tax rates in the Eisenhower era (, or maybe something in that direction).

I don't believe the circa 1994 income surge among the lowest earners means squat.The early 90s recession was in fact a full blown depression with foot-tall stacks of resumes submitted for every crappy job and unemployed college graduates losing not only their freshman through senior year flab through hunger, but much of their muscle mass.  I saw it with my eyes. It was like the 30s dust bowl. My friends looked like the Joads.  People forget.  I don't, and I won't. No nicer than 2008-2012.But my point: the post recession was not some Clinton miracle: when a recession ends, wages rebound. It's the cycle. Maybe some good policy choices helped get that rebound, but any rebound from starvation income levels will seem like an economic boom.

"If something isn't impossible, there must be a way to do it," said the recently passed away hero Nicholas Winton.I'm taking my cue from him, and some recent browsing at Martha Nussbaum's attempts to restore classical Greek democratic ethical principles.  (And indeed, maybe a bit of Pixar "Inside Out" on the benefits of ostensibly negative emotions.) DRUMROLL... Tatatatatata.....SHAME SHAME SHAME.  That's how! SHAME the hyper wealthy who "earn" disproportionately to their effort and talent, which together are what people call "merit" and the criteria of FAIRNESS.On all tax returns, force all filers to sign a statement that their income ratios, is, income relative to average incomes, are DESERVED based on effort and talent. A hedge fund manager or fortunate heir receiving 10,000x a nurse's income should sign a declaration this ratio is warranted based on merit.  Most would decline, in which case that should sign a declaration that though not "merited,"it's "legally" earned, and they want to keep the funds.If they opt for the latter, they should be subject to a wealth tax based on the income ratios of organizations from which their wealth was earned. The higher the ratio (highest earner to lowest), the higher the tax rate, thus incentivizing more equitable pay.

God this is dreadful.  Your data is at least.  You make the dubious assumption that incomes for the 10% would remain the same if the minimum wage was raised to $15, which is untrue. If it did, I can assure you the top 10% of wages would not have increased as the rate they did, narrowing the gap,

The rentier-class calls themselves "job creators." The plain fact is that they have not been creating many jobs, particularly not creating good jobs, for the middle class and below.The US is no longer "the land of opportunity:" homesteading ended long ago.  Everything is owned, and increasingly a very few people own the overwhelming fraction.  It is the nature of wealth and empire for the wealthy to use the power of their wealth to avoid taxation -- to shift the taxation onto the lower classes.  This is "clientelism" writ large, or even outright oligopoly.   It is the way nations die -- the Roman Empire died this way, the French and Russian revolutions happened this way.When Romney talked about "the takers" he was using rentier dog-whistle language for "these people have no right to live, we don't want them anymore."  We all got it, Mitch.  Those are the people who fought WWII and are now very old.  They are the people who fought in Viet Nam and are now my age -- many of them never got a good job afterwards.  And many who fought in Afghanistan or Iraq are unemployed, or scrambling to stay afloat working several  burger-flipping/retail  jobs.  All of the "little people" are the customers, those who pay rent.  Henry Ford understood that capitalism meant creating a market for the products; that wages needed to be enough so that people could have some discretionary income.  People should read "Tin Horns and Calico" -- about the rent wars, and think.

The ones at the top have taken all of the wealth from the bottom. We are living through the largest transfer of wealth to the top 1% in our nation's history, thanks in a large part, to the gutless and worthless federal reserve.

This drop in status is especially true among families of color, short sellers of property, and victims of vicious off-shoring. Go get 'em Bernie Sanders.  This is your time to shine!

It's not really inequality, it is poverty.The purpose for taxing the rich is to make government that will lift people out of poverty.Getting good schools, people educated and working and paying taxes instead of welfare or in prison.But changing the culture of poverty is not only costly, it is a lot of work. "The Clinton years had very impressive economic growth over all, some of which benefited families in the bottom 90 percent. The Comedy Party advocates Welfare for All, replacing the welfare now paid only to the rich and the poor.  Today, the poor receive food stamps, sometimes rent stamps, and sometimes tax refunds. The rest of us get nothing.If everyone received a payment equal to the poverty level plus $1, there would no longer be any poverty.  The economy would boom because demand would zoom upward. Senator McGovern liked the idea.To see this and other common sense steps, go to YouTube and watch Comedy Party Platform (2 min 9 sec). A couple of observations:  1)I believe the Piety/Saez data includes capital gains, 2)The period 2009-2014 saw a major bull market, resulting from the fed-induced drop in interest rates.  It is not surprising that the result is huge "income" for those with large equity positions.  The results would look quite different if the starting/ending points encompassed a bear market--say 2007 to 2009.  Also, consider that the Internal Revenue Code requirements on deductibility of executive compensation have driven a major shift to equity based deferred compensation, which also distorts average income numbers during the bull phase of the equity markets.  The biggest thing that could be done to reduce inequality as reported here would be for the fed to raise interest rates sharply.  Everybody would be poorer, but the property owning classes would see a bigger percentage drop in reported income as capital gains disappear.

The idea that low-income workers' wages could be raised by increasing the minimum wage is a chimera.   If the existing minimum-wage workers can't do $15 worth of work an hour, then they will not be hired.   Their jobs will be taken by others who can do $15 an hour worth of work.In order to raise up the people at the bottom, we have to increase their skills and education so that they have more to offer to employers.   Otherwise, they will simply be shuttled aside, and join the permanently unemployed.

"As a practical matter, it’s highly unlikely that you could increase income growth for the bottom 90 percent without also lifting income growth for those at the top, thereby increasing inequality."Is this a problem?This article illustrates that focusing on "inequality" is pointless misdirection. What does it matter what the 1% or 10% make? If they are taxed more to reduce their earnings narrowing the gap will lower paid worker be better off?Focusing on pathways to better paying jobs is a worthwhile goal. Fixating on the spread in not.

Seems like the nation could regain some of the greatness and prosperity it once had if we simply went back to the more historically progressive rates.

Bernie Sanders is shaping up to be the "Mr. Walks-On-Water" of this election.Al Gore lost his bid for the presidency in Florida but not just because of Jeb Bush and the U.S. Supreme Court.Ralph Nader -- who was the "Mr. Walks-On-Water" of that election -- had promised that he would NOT campaign in Florida if the polls showed Al Gore and George W. Bush in a tight race. The polls did show a very tight race, but "Mr. Walks-On-Water" Nader campaigned there anyway despite his promise.Ralph Nader garnered 95,000 votes in Florida. If he had stayed out of Florida, many voters among that 95,000 would have voted for Al Gore --  putting Gore OUT OF THE REACH of Jeb and/or the U.S. Supreme Court.Now, this year's version of "Mr. Walks-On-Water" seems to be Bernie Sanders. 2016 is a fight for Democracy vs Oligarchy.Sen. Sanders is the only one talking about it and he submitted a bill to raise some of the money needed to actualise his solutions:Sanders’ bill does the following: link below with video of press conference•	Lowers the estate tax exemption level from $5.4 million to $3.5 million for individuals and from about $11 million to $7 million for couples.•	Increases the marginal tax rate to 45 percent on estates between $3.5 million to $10 million, 50 percent on estates between $10 million and $50 million, and 55 percent on estates over $50 million.•	Creates a new billionaire surtax of 10 percent that would only impact 530 billionaires who are worth a combined $2.6 trillion.•	Ends loopholes allowing billionaire families to set up dynasty trusts to avoid taxes.•	Closes loopholes used by the wealthy to avoid estate taxes.•	Protects family farms and conservation easements.Sanders Proposes Tax on Billionaires to Reduce Wealth Inequality is the only candidate not forming a 'Super Pac'.

So tired of the media trying to frame the discussion by calling Bernie unelectable, fringe, extreme etc. why can't you discuss real issues and what the candidates propose as solutions? I'm 61 years old. If Bernie can defeat Hillary in the primaries, for the first time in my life in a general presidential election, I will feel I am not voting for the best of two evils, but rather for someone who is really determined to do good and what is best for the People, rather than what is best for himself. They will do their best to paint him as an extremist socialist, playing the same political games with the gullible, patriotic voters that the fear-mongering Republicans always put up as their only effective strategy, and they may succeed, but damn, this is the first contender in decades who promises to put us on a new road, instead of the corrupted highway that has brought us Homeland Security and Iraq, broken the economy, and put hundreds of paid corporate operatives into our Congress to explicitly vote against the best interests of the People. Bernie gives me hope, and like TR and FDR, the monied interests in both parties will aim all their heavy artillery against him, and yet the People may see that he is a man of true honesty and conviction, and may put him into office with the only power left to them, the vote. Of all declared candidates, Sanders’ views and values come closest to mine and I will undoubtedly support him during the primary season. But let’s not kid ourselves that he will cruise to the nomination (much less prevail in the general) as did Obama. This will not be 2008 redux.Despite its location, Chicago is demographically a N'eastern blue-leaning megalopolis. But even “deep-blue” states turn “red” outside the cities. Outside NYC, LA, SF, Chicago, DC, Seattle, Portland, and major university towns he’ll be a much tougher sell than Obama ever was. Why? First, the “S”-word.  Regardless of how reasonable his principles may sound when described, most far-suburban, exurban and rural voters (especially Boomers & older) will hear the word “Socialist” and think “Commie” instead. (And if they don’t at first, FOXNews--their “trusted” news source--will certainly hammer it over and over again till that meme “takes”).Even more sadly, Sanders’ Judaism (however secular) will be a dealbreaker for most heartlanders. In 2000, numerous push-poll calls concerning Lieberman, at first neutral-sounding, ended with the question “Are you comfortable with someone who denies our Lord & Savior Jesus Christ being a heartbeat away from the Presidency?” Our last non-Christian Pres. was Jefferson; and Obama’s declared Christianity may have reassured rural voters and thus saved his candidacy among them. Sanders will likely not be that lucky.But I hope I’m wrong.

What most people don't realize is that there are NO Absentee Ballots in caucus states -- one sizeable chunk of Hillary's stalwarts can not participate -- many older women & single working mothers with children. In 2008, I heard over & over: "Oh honey, I can't caucus, I'm a cripple." "I LOVE Hillary but I can't make it across that icy parking lot at the school." "I have lingering pneumonia and I'm bedbound -- but my *mind* is fine -- I should be able to vote Absentee." The idea that these folks can "get a ride" is ludicrous. They need a primary -- where they can vote absentee. Also caucuses do NOT have secret ballots. A lady I phoned in Nevada in 2008 said her sister called her from a small NV town and said, "Mary, if my boss knew I was for Hillary, I wouldn't have a job on Monday." An Iowa official told me, "If we're not a caucus, we're not first in the nation." True. Caucuses are fine for activists,but not for the public at large. Go back and look at the numbers in 2008. Primaries/Hillary. Caucuses/Obama. Caucuses are cute but they are NOT democratic.

I believe the deciding factor for Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton may be foreign relations. Outspoken as he is on many crucial issues, I notice that Mr. Sanders has yet to extensively tackle the thorny bush of diplomacy – and even if he has, his approach aren't as widely known. How does he plan to handle the Middle East crisis? China and Russia? What of North Africa? Many potential voters would love to know. The three tabs on his website's On the Issues page ("Income and Wealth Inequality", "Getting Big Money Out of Politics", "Climate Change & Environment") are undoubtedly important, but perhaps Mr. Sanders should consider adding a fourth in the near future: Foreign Policy.One might argue that such a move is risky. International affairs are hardly static, wrong calls never look good, and you cannot satisfy everyone. But Mr. Sanders is well informed, up-to-date, and consistent in his voting record. If Donald Trump is unafraid to present a concise (if woefully juvenile) game plan for foreign policy, I venture to say that it wouldn't hurt Mr. Sanders to present his own as well – and ahead of Mrs. Clinton.

Buckley, Jr. famously stated, unequivocally, in the first issue of  “National Review” (1955) that his conservative mandate was to stand “athwart history, yelling Stop.”In his preface to “God and Man at Yale” Buckley wrote two of his most philosophically and historically important sentences:"I myself believe that the duel between Christianity and atheism is the most important in the world.""I further believe that the struggle between individualism and collectivism is the same struggle reproduced on another level.”Current conservative thought is sentimental and/or emotional, not an articulated, rationally stated argument. So far, the debate on Trump's immigration proposal has been largely fact free.  Fortunately, the Congressional Research Service recently published "Sanctuary Jurisdictions and Criminal Aliens:  In Brief" which puts into some  context law breaking by those in the United States unlawfully.  The CRS reports that as of the end of 2013 of the 214,000 people in our federal prisons 54,000 were non-citizens, almost all of which were here unlawfully.  That is 25%.  An additional 47,000 were in state prisons. Trump's proposal to expel these criminals from the United States seems reasonable.

Personally, I think that the conservatives have come to the price to be paid for their long battle to silence critical reporting by journalists which has succeeded in one way or the other leaving us with a press that seeks to keep the powerful happy and the rest of the people entertained to keep ratings up. The totally biased and well spun views of the most interested parties are usually reported without any critical reporting as balanced reporting. The most sensational stories take up hours of news time to avoid missing critical audiences and leaving most news unreported to most people. This leaves those with power and influence able to function without the annoyance of press and public distracting their efforts, but it leaves most people without any substantial understanding of the issues like immigration or health care or international affairs, allowing politics to dominate all issues because the electorate is just not well informed. It has worked well for conservatives and given them the ability to dominate in a country where most people are more liberal socially and more conservative fiscally. But it has given Trump a constituency of ill informed people whose attitudes Trump is representing well.

We let immigrants in with weak controls, if any, in place because we wanted their labor. We've let millions of them stay here and work for years: any of us could find a hundred undocumented immigrants in an hour. We've all benefited from their work, and they have been treated unfairly. It's time to show ourselves a better country than this. Let's not have this go down in our history as a second wave of what is to some degree at least a form of slavery: we can pay you less, make you work longer hours, don't insure you, cut you out of all workers' benefits, and hold a threat over your heads every day.Right-wing extremists seem to love nothing more than simplicity and certainly. Reality, not so much. We're obviously not even capable of deported 11 or 12 million people, even if we wanted to. But aren't we big deals when we bluster, moralize, and pontificate?Yes, we need much better border controls, for multiple reasons.But we also need to treat our present population, whether documented or undocumented/exploited, honorably and fairly.

The GOP has already spent almost all the first year of their new majority trying to undo everything the president has done — essentially rolling back the clock. They are defending the isolation of Cuba against the wishes of most young Cuban-Americans. They are pushing to restore a family-destroying deportation policy, even though Obama’s de-emphasis on sending illegal immigrants home has already given him a 15-point boost among Latinos. They continue to push taking away health insurance for millions who never had it before. They insist that nothing can be done on climate change, despite an agreement on the table for the world’s two biggest polluters, the United States and China, to do something significant.It raises the question of why this happening even though the popular vote in the last election was very much in favor of the Democrats, yet a GOP-dominated congress prevailed precipitating a deliberate paralysis of government, where a rump is holding the whole place to ransom. It doesn't really jibe with the notion of the US as a global leader with a bunch of gleeful stalwart obstructionists holding court whose sole aim is to thwart Obama's governance with political impunity because through deliberate GOP gerrymandering their seats are safe. This is an insidious form of plutocracy. It's a sinister development where elements of a ruinous anarchy are now emerging.

At one point, a few months ago, I wanted Democrats to re-register as Republicans to guarantee that Trump would head a losing ticket. Now I'm far less sure that either he'll lose or that any positive candidate would win. The responses on this list are terrifying to anyone with the constitution as more than a myth: Trump's rants about "lawyers" who justify his game, no less than candidates like Jindal and Cruse and Rubio, show how far politics has descended and the outrageous stupidity of an unconstitutional rant. How, for example, Trump would "force" Mexico to build a wall, and avoid other walls in Canada, for just one example is - on its face - absurd, let alone racist and against 90% of the American immigration tradition.

Trump's rhetoric is over the top, and many of his policy proposals are either unrealistic or severely lacking in details.  But give him this: he taking positions that were previously considered third rail, and the response has been overwhelmingly positive.  And not just on the right.The political class on both sides has been out of step with most Americans.  Democratic politicians love the thought of importing new Democrats who will keep them in power.  And crony capitalist Republicans (and Democrats) are in bed with the chamber of commerce which wants to keep open the flow of cheap labor.But for the rest of us, we're being taken for a ride.  And especially lower income Americans.  Low-skilled illegal immigrants have been taking their jobs, and depressing their wage rates, and destroying their union leverage, and flooding their schools will kids who speak little English and have little prior education, for years.  This isn't a right wing issue.  This is a populist issue, which the ruling class needs to wake up to.  The Donald is just the messenger.

Honestly, it's hard to know where to begin.  I'm reminded of Chauncey Gardner without the humanity. I watch Trump's town meeting, press conference and am reminded how the press is an enabler and the rest are lemmings.  And he is a factually challenged buffoon who uses insults to skip substance.It is at once entertaining and frightening.  It is farce without the French and slamming doors.  It is not a profile in courage for any of the players.It is just sad commentary on a once principled party in the death throes.It is the slow death of facts and a continuation of misplaced anger.And in the end nothing gets discussed, nothing gets fixed and we are all the lesser for it.
